title: Quarto Workshop
text:
What is Quarto?
Quarto is a modern, interactive publishing system built on pandoc:

Converts Markdown files to multiple formats:

html/rmarkdown/pdf
Reveal.js (slides, pptx)
Jupyter Notebooks (ipynb)
ePub, Typst, LaTex and more


origin: org-mode (Emacs) => Sweave / knitr => RMarkdown

title: Quarto Workshop
text:
Why Use Quarto?

Focus on reproducibility
Easy interactivity
Flexible output formats
Good processing of code blocks:

R
Python
Julia
ObservableJS

title: Quarto Workshop
text:
Setting Up Your Environment

Create a new directory for the workshop:
mkdir quarto-workshop
cd quarto-workshop
Create a Conda environment:
conda create -n quarto-env python=3.10 -y
conda activate quarto-env
Initialize Git:
git init

title: Quarto Workshop
text:
Introducing qmd
Basic features:

document metadata block at the top of file:

title: "blah"
format: "html"
date: "2025-01-22"
#| hash-pipe blocks to configure code blocks
::: fence blocks are used for quarto & custom css divs and classes

::: {.class}
::: {#id}
::: {.class #id}

title: Quarto Workshop
text:
Example qmd

Write a small example.qmd file:
---   
title: "Demo"
format: html
---
# Hello, Quarto!
::: {.panel-tabset}
### Tab 1
Content for tab 1.
### Tab 2
Content for tab 2.
:::
Render the file:
quarto render example.qmd

Exercise
Write a .qmd file with fenced divs.

title: Quarto Workshop
text:
Simple qmd Code Blocks
Quarto supports executing code blocks in markdown files.
Python

def greet(name):
    print(f"Hello, {name}!")
greet("Quarto")

Hello, Quarto!


Javascript
#| echo: true
console.log("Hello, Quarto!")
Exercise
Create a .qmd file with a Python and R code block.

title: Quarto Workshop
text:
Enhanced Code Blocks: Hash Pipe (#|)
You can control the behavior of code blocks using the hash pipe (#|) syntax. This allows you to specify options like displaying code, showing output, or even setting execution parameters.
   #| echo: true
   #| warning: false
   def greet(name):
      print(f"Hello, {name}!")
The #| syntax adds more control over the execution and display of the code block.
Exercise

Create a .qmd file with a Python code block using the #| options like echo, warning, and eval.

title: Quarto Workshop
text:
Create a Blog Project

Create a Quarto blog project:
quarto create-project blog --type website
Initialize Git and create branches:
git init
git checkout -b blog-setup
Write an environment file:
name: blog-env
channels:
  - conda-forge
dependencies:
  - python=3.10
  - quarto
Activate the environment:
conda env create -f environment.yml
conda activate blog-env

Exercise: Create a blog project and explain the directory structure.

title: Quarto Workshop
text:
Writing a Blog Post

Create a new .qmd file in the posts folder:

title: "My First Blog Post"
date: 2025-01-20


# Welcome!

This is my first post using **Quarto**!
Render and preview:
quarto preview

title: Quarto Workshop
text:
Configure GitHub Pages

Configure _quarto.yml:
project:
  type: website
publish:
  gh-pages:
    branch: gh-pages
configure repo settings to publish from gh-pages branch
Push to GitHub:
git add .
git commit -m "Initial blog setup"
git push origin blog-setup
Merge to main and deploy.

title: Quarto Workshop
text:
Group Exercise
Collaborate on a Blog

Form groups of 3–4 persons, have one person who is advanced in github flow.
Each group member creates a branch:
git checkout -b member_initials/feature-branch-name
Write posts in the posts/ directory.
Merge branches to main.
Push and share your blog URL.
